Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of Ultralight Biophotonic Neuro-cellular Imaging Platform for Elucidating Brain Activity in Freely-behaving Animals

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Li, Xingde
Proposal: 1430040
Title: MRI: Development of Ultralight Biophotonic Neuro-cellular Imaging Platform for Elucidating Brain Activity in Freely-behaving Animals

Significance
Development of this imaging platform will positively impact human lives, particularly in the areas of health care, safety, and human assistance, due to its portability, miniature probe design, and ability to operate in multiple modalities. The neuroscience research
will impact education, rehabilitation, and mental-health. The project involves people at many career stages, offering a rich multidisciplinary environment that integrates science and engineering. Detailed system designs and research results will be widely disseminated, accelerating the pace of neuroscience discovery. Exposure to this platform will allow scientists to extend their research into new physiological and pathological contexts. Moreover, the proposed imaging platform has significant clinical translation potential, as it enables minimally invasive visualization of cellular characteristics in vivo, in situ and in real time, without the need for tissue removal, which can be readily adapted for diagnostic analysis of other organ systems.

Technical Description:
This Major Research Instrument (MRI) project aims to develop an ultracompact, portable and head-mountable imaging platform, which will enable imaging of brain activity with subcellular resolution in freely behaving animals. The core of the platform is a novel fiber-optic, scanning two-photon fluorescence endomicroscope which is not commercially available. This ultra-microscope is capable of visualizing cellular activity with an imaging quality approaching that of large bench-top microscopy systems. In addition, a small footprint, tunable femtosecond Ti:Sapphire laser will also be developed and integrated to provide a portable platform for two-photon excitation. To facilitate identification of specific brain regions for high resolution imaging, a 2-mm fiber-optic confocal probe with a large field of view (FOV) will be developed and integrated into the platform; this confocal probe will be exchangeable with the two-photon ultra-microscope through the same head-mount base. The confocal probe also enables high-speed imaging of cellular dynamics, complementing the two-photon endomicroscope. The end result of this development effort will be a unique, highly adaptable imaging platform for shared-use, which can be transported to specific facilities/labs across JHU to address specific research questions. The imaging platform will be developed in close collaboration with four research labs at JHU that are engaged in studies of cellular and subcellular dynamics in the intact brain and whose studies have been limited by existing microscope-based imaging platforms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Head-mounted Endomicroscopy Platforms for Multi-scale Freely-moving Imaging in vivo

With support from the NSF MRI grant we developed two novel integrated imaging platforms that, on different resolving scales and imaging field of view, enable visualization of cellular activity and behavior synchronously in unrestrained small rodents.

The first ultracompact platform is a single-photon confocal device based on a multicore coherent fiber bundle of a 650 μm diameter containing 30K individual fibers, along with an achromatic micro-objective lens of a 0.85 NA and a >1 mm working distance attached to the end of the probe.  This confocal imaging probe is directly mounted on (or detached from) the animal head through a cranial window. Astrocytes in the cerebral cortex that contain genetically encoded fluorophores (eGFP, GCaMP3) can be continuously imaged at cellular resolution for > 24 hrs in freely moving animals with sufficient stability. This imaging platform has distinct advantages over alternative technologies (such as head mounted epifluorescence microscopes), including light weight, low cost, and adaptability. In addition, dual-color imaging is also possible with the confocal probe, enabling simultaneous assessment of different cellular activities in vivo.

The second platform is a fiber-optic scanning two-photon endomicroscope, which enables visualization of sub-cellular events, as well as the activity of small elements (e.g. individual synapses and axonal arbors). The ultracompact (2.1-2.8 mm in diameter), and ultralight (< 1.5 g) two-photon probe can be mounted on (or detached from) the head of a freely-moving mouse through a cranial window for real time imaging of neuro activities. This system consists of: (i) a femtosecond laser (such as a customized compact Ti:Sapphire laser), (ii) a piezoelectric based resonant fiber scanner, (iii) a noise-reduced double-clad fiber, (iv) a super achromatic micro-objective lens, and (v) a head-mount with a tri-axis manipulator. This platform offers a subcellular resolution (0.8 um x 7 um, lateral x axial), a 120 – 300 um field of view, and a working distance of ~350 mm, enabling visualization of structures in layer I or II/III of the cortex through a 50 µm-thick cranial window. This system has been tested for its ability to resolve individual neuromodulatory axonal, neuronal dendritic and astrocytic microdomain activity, using mice that were genetically engineered to express the calcium indicator GCaMP6 in different cell types. Continuous high-resolution imaging for more than 30 min can be conveniently performed with superb stability. This imaging platform provides a means to obtain detailed information about subcellular signaling events in different behavior contexts. As it is clear that cellular activity is greatly influenced by animal state, this system is poised to greatly expand our knowledge about the dynamics of different neuromodulatory projections in the cortex, and the mechanisms that enable local signaling in astrocyte microdomains and neuronal dendrites.
